required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Regional Anesthesia Versus General Anesthesia in Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Gynecological Surgery

lead_sponsor.agency: Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria di Bologna Policlinico S. Orsola Malpighi

clinical_study.source: Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria di Bologna Policlinico S. Orsola Malpighi

brief_summary.textblock: Patients undergoing laparoscopic gynecological surgery will receive regional anesthesia or general anesthesia with endotracheal intubation. The investigators aim to evaluate the feasibility and safety of regional anesthesia for laparoscopic gynecological procedures.

detailed_description.textblock:
Commonly, laparoscopic gynecological procedures are performed under general anesthesia with endotracheal intubation.
The use of regional anesthesia in laparoscopy is reserved to patients declared unfit for general anesthesia because of severe comorbidities or it is applied in combination with general anesthesia to decrease postoperative pain.
Recently, growing literature evidence supports the use of regional anesthesia in patients undergoing laparoscopy.
The combination of minimally invasive surgery with regional anesthesia could increase the advantages of laparoscopic operations (less postoperative pain, shorter hospital stay, etc).

primary_outcome.measure: Feasibility and safety: Clavien-Dindo Classification (from Grade I to V)
primary_outcome.time_frame: From the surgery time, assessed up to 7 days after surgery
primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of feasibility and safety of regional anesthesia for gynecological laparoscopic surgery, considering complications using Clavien-Dindo Classification (from Grade I to V)

secondary_outcome.description: evaluation of the presence of postoperative nausea or emesis.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From surgery to hospitalization discharge, assessed up to 7 days after surgery.
secondary_outcome.description: Number of days of hospitalization after surgery.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From surgery to day of first mobilization, assessed up to 7 days after surgery.
secondary_outcome.description: Day of first mobilization after surgery.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From surgery to day of first feeding, assessed up to 7 days after surgery.
secondary_outcome.description: Day of first feeding after surgery.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From surgery to day of first canalization, assessed up to 7 days after surgery.
secondary_outcome.description: Day of first canalization after surgery.

secondary_outcome.measure: Intraoperative pain: verbal numeric rating scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative: from skin incision to cutaneous suture.
secondary_outcome.description: Intraoperative pain in patients submitted to regional anesthesia (Group B), using a verbal numeric rating scale, from 0 to 10, where 0 is no pain and 10 is the worse pain ever

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative: from skin incision to cutaneous suture.
Intraoperative: from anesthesia to the beginning of pneumoperitoneum induction.
secondary_outcome.description: End-Tidal PCO2 is measured by capnography.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative: pneumoperitoneum time expressed in minutes.
secondary_outcome.description: End-Tidal PCO2 is measured by capnography.

Evaluation of postoperative pain in patients undergoing general or regional anesthesia for gynecological laparoscopic surgery, measured with verbal numerical rating scale, from 0 to 10, where 0 is no pain and 10 is the worse pain ever

arm_group.description: Patients undergoing gynecological laparoscopic surgery under general anesthesia, using the following drugs: Midazolam, Propofol, Sufentanil, Rocuronium, Sevoflurane
Patients undergoing gynecological laparoscopic surgery under regional anesthesia, using the following drugs: Sufentanil, Bupivacaine

intervention.description: Used for general anesthesia for gynecological laparoscopic procedures, together with Propofol, Sufentanil, Rocuronium, Sevoflurane

Used for regional anesthesia (spinal or combined spinal-epidural anesthesia) for gynecological laparoscopic procedures together with Bupivacaine; and for general anesthesia for gynecological laparoscopic procedures, together with following drugs: Midazolam, Propofol, Rocuronium, Sevoflurane
Used for general anesthesia for gynecological laparoscopic procedures, together with the following drugs: Midazolam, Sufentanil, Rocuronium, Sevoflurane
Used for general anesthesia for gynecological laparoscopic procedures, together with the following drugs: Midazolam, Propofol, Sufentanil, Sevoflurane
Used for general anesthesia for gynecological laparoscopic procedures, together with the following drugs: Midazolam, Propofol, Sufentanil, Rocuronium
Used for regional anesthesia (spinal or combined spinal-epidural anesthesia) for gynecological laparoscopic procedures, together with Sufentanil

facility.name: Cardiothoracic and Vascular Anesthesia and Intensive Care, S. OrsolaMalpighi University Hospital
Gynecology and Physiopathology of Human Reproductive Unit, University of Bologna, S. Orsola-Malpighi Hospital

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria di Bologna Policlinico S. Orsola Malpighi
